entry.title: Combined summary - Compressed Bitcoin Transactions
entry.summary:
Tom Briar and Andrew Poelstra have developed a Compressed Transaction Schema designed to significantly decrease the size of Bitcoin transactions. This technology is particularly advantageous for applications such as steganography, satellite/radio broadcasts, and peer-to-peer communication in environments with limited bandwidth but high CPU availability. The schema employs techniques like metadata packing, variable-length integers, compressed signatures, and a substitution of the txid/vout pair with block height and index for compression.
The approach utilizes CompactSize and VarInt primitives for efficient numeric encoding, transaction metadata for decoding structure, and encodes input and output metadata to minimize space usage. It also identifies an ideal transaction type for optimal compression and provides test vectors to illustrate byte savings after compression.
Noteworthy advancements include replacing nLocktime with relative block height for all Compressed Inputs and introducing a second type of Variable Integer. These changes are documented in a Draft PR available at: [Reference Impl/Draft PR](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/29134), with detailed methods outlined in the [Compressed Transaction Schema](https://github.com/TomBriar/bitcoin/blob/2023-05--tx-compression/doc/compressed_transactions.md) documentation.
The importance of this work lies in its potential to facilitate transmission of transaction information efficiently. The schema allows omission and reconstruction of certain data upon decompression, which could be crucial for specific use cases where bandwidth is scarce.
In email exchanges, Tom discusses optimizing lock times and using reference heights for transaction size reduction. He proposes grinding block height rather than lock time for space savings and suggests brute-forcing different reference heights to validate signatures. He plans to update the codebase with historical trends and fuzz testing data, implementing a 100-block threshold against blockchain reorganization in a forthcoming pull request.
The conversation also touches on eliminating the vout from encoding, using block height and index instead, and the rejection of using ordinals for indexing transaction outputs due to complexity and potential user confusion.
Feedback from Fabian includes suggestions for improving the UTXO set index's efficiency, potentially saving space and supporting pruning compatibility. Meanwhile, Andrew requests a chart demonstrating the compression schema's effectiveness for specific transactions to better understand its application.
Tom's contribution is a compression schema for bitcoin transactions, focusing on those most commonly used, aiming to preserve the integrity of transactions while transmitting over platforms with limited bandwidth but capable of handling decompression. His involvement progresses with a pull request to incorporate the compression schema into practice.
